intro: Agalinis purpurea var. chiapasana, commonly known as the Chiapas purple bluemouth, is a flowering plant native to the highlands of Chiapas, Mexico. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its striking violet to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as rocky slopes and grasslands. It produces small, tubular flowers that attract pollinators like bees and hummingbirds. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
